this was my house when I was a child I
lived with my grandparents between when
I was mmm 1 & 6 but I came back very

and this was part of our weekly ritual
it's Thursday night trash night we are
fully mobilized and ready to go we have
gathered in my grandfather's 1940 sedan
waiting to be deployed to dig through
every trash heap overflowing from the

we've come for your radios any radios no

unheated wooden cubicle in a tiny corner
of our house here winter and summer
magic occurs here in a room filled with
electrical wire and filament tubes I
will sit studiously at his side while he
wires
Salter's and exchanges bad tubes for
good we wait together for the same
moment that instant when the whispering
breath the beautiful low static hum and
warm sundown glow of electricity will
come surging back into the dead
skeletons of radio as we've pulled from
extinction here at my grandfather's
workbench the resurrection is real the
vacuum of silence will be drawn up and
filled with the distant crackling voices
of Sunday preachers blabbering pitchman
big-band music early rock-and-roll
shouters and serial dramas it's the
sound of the world outside straining to
reach us calling down to our little town
and deeper into our hermetically sealed
universe here at 87 Randolph Street once
returned to the living all items will be
sold for $5 in the migrant camps that
come summer will dot the farm fields on
the edge of our borough the radio man is
coming that's how my grandfather is
known amongst the mostly southern black
migrant population that returns by bus
every season to harvest the crops of
rural Monmouth County down the dirt farm
roads to the shacks in the rear where
Dust Bowl thirties conditions live on my
mother drives my stroke addled grandpa
to do his business amongst the blacks in
their Mickey Mouse camps I went once and
I was frightened out of my wits
surrounded in the dusk by hard worn
black faces race relations never great
and freehold will explode 10 years
later into rioting and shootings but for
now there's just a steady uncomfortable
quiet I'm simply the young Protege
grandson of the radio man here amongst
his patrons were my family scrambles to
